Next, we need to understand what is meant by "two full rotations of debris." This refers to the amount of time it takes for the debris in the patch to move in a circular pattern due to ocean currents. One rotation would indicate the time it takes for the debris to complete one full circle, while two rotations would indicate the time it takes for the debris to complete two full circles and return to its original location.

Therefore, the correct answer is (A) yes, as the patch was discovered in 2010 and less than 10 years have passed since then, meaning it has not completed two full rotations of debris.
